text: The overrated Coen brothers shouldn't be given the job of writing this movie's screenplay. That's like letting an atheist write about the historical account of Noah.  In Zamperini's autobiography "Devil at my heels",  Louis makes it crystal clear that the most important part and message of his life isn't about being an Olympic runner, POW survivor. perseverance, determination, or even breaking the all time record of surviving on a raft in the middle of the ocean for 47 days.  It's about the power of Jesus Christ to free us from sin and and  the destructive hold of hate, and the supernatural transformation of being able to even forgive your worst enemies. That's why Zamperini when he sold his story to Universal put in a legal clause that forbids them to exclude his Jesus Christ born again experience.  How can the Coen brothers write about something they can't possibly truly comprehend.  To miss the most important message of Zamperin's life is tragic.  This will be  like Homer missing the main point of Harper Lee's masterpiece  "Books are useless! I only ever read one book, To Kill A Mockingbird, and it gave me absolutely no insight on how to kill mockingbirds! Sure it taught me not to judge a man by the color of his skin . . . but what good does that do me?"  Homer Simpson

text: This movie was nothing less of greatness in documenting a man’s life so epic on all human capacity. Louis fought with peace and integrity not just for his family, friends or his enemies, but for humanity. We will all die at some point in our lifetime; what do you want the world to remember you as? Despite, many critics and their open opinions about the film, we can't deny the bravery that exist within this film of which depicted Louis Zamperini and many who illuminated his life. Throughout this movie his life broadcast many struggles beyond war, beyond men, beyond race, beyond countries’ borders, but of deep faith beyond persecution.  We can only image someone else’s pain until we have walked in their shoes. Unbroken has taught me to never let someone still your joy and forgive, not just for the other person, but mostly for you.
